artefact.alternative_title: Aortic or brain aneurysm and driving
artefact.overview: You must tell DVLA if you've had an aneurysm
artefact.body:
You must tell DVLA if you have a brain aneurysm and you may need to tell them about an aortic aneurysm.

You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.

Car or motorcycle licence

Aortic aneurysm

You only need to tell DVLA if your aortic aneurysm is over 6 centimetres in diameter despite treatment. Ask your doctor or consultant if you’re not sure.

If you need to tell DVLA, fill in form H1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘H1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 299KB)

Brain aneurysm

You must tell DVLA if you’ve had a brain aneurysm. Fill in form B1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘B1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 306KB)

Bus, coach or lorry licence

Aortic aneurysm

You must tell DVLA if you’ve had an aortic aneurysm of any size. Fill in form VOCH1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘VOCH1 Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 394KB)

Brain aneurysm

You must tell DVLA if you’ve had a brain aneurysm. Fill in form B1 and send to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘B1 Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 306KB)
